official-title.#text: To authorize the Secretary of Education to make grants to States to improve the knowledge, credentials, compensation, and professional development of early childhood educators working with children in early childhood education programs.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Education and the Workforce

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text: Early Childhood Education Professional Improvement Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

The purpose of this Act is to provide assistance to States to improve the knowledge, credentials, compensation, and professional development of early childhood educators working with children in early childhood education programs.
In this Act:

quote.#tail: means a Head Start Program carried out under the

text.#text: The term

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , a State-funded prekindergarten program, a licensed child care serving prekindergarten children, and special education preschool.

quote.#tail: has the meaning given the term in

text.#text: The term

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 101(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , is authorized to award grants to States to implement and administer the activities described in
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Secretary of Health and Human Services

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Early Childhood Education Professional Improvement Act of 2013/s:6

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: at such time, in such manner, and accompanied by such information as the

text.#text: Each State desiring a grant under this Act shall submit an application to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall include a description of the State’s comprehensive early childhood professional development system, including the following:
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Early Childhood Education Professional Improvement Act of 2013/s:5/ss:a

text.#text: Each application submitted under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the State agency responsible for administering childcare, the State Head Start collaboration director, the State educational agency, institutions of higher education, organizations that represent early childhood educators, and credible early childhood education professional organizations.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 642B of the Head Start Act

text.#text: A description of how the State’s system was developed in collaboration with the State Advisory Council on Early Childhood Education and Care designated or established under
A designation of a State agency to administer the grant program.
A description of how the State’s system provides—
an oversight structure for the system;
professional standards and competencies;
a career lattice;
coordination with State higher education agencies, higher education accrediting bodies, and accredited two- and four-year institutions of higher education;

encouragement of articulation agreements between two- and four-year institutions of higher education and credit-bearing opportunities and articulation agreements that recognize prior learning and expertise;
more accessible higher education for working learners through offering of college courses at accessible time and locations, with particular attention to rural areas;
support to adult learners who are dual language learners, or come from low-income or minority communities;
use of workforce data to assess the State’s workforce needs; and
its financing over time.
A State that receives a grant under this Act shall ensure that grant funds are used to carry out the following:

To provide scholarships to cover the costs of tuition, fees, materials, transportation, paid substitutes, and release time for preschool teachers employed in an early childhood education program to pursue a bachelor’s degree in early childhood education or a closely related field.

To support preschool teachers employed in an early childhood education program, and who have obtained a bachelor’s degree in a field other than early childhood education or a closely related field, to attain a credential, licensure, or endorsement that demonstrates competence in early childhood education.

To increase compensation for teachers who are enrolled and making progress toward a degree in early childhood education and to provide parity of compensation upon completion of such degree and retention in the early childhood education program.
To provide ongoing professional development opportunities to preschool teachers and teacher assistants employed in an early childhood education program that address—
all areas of child development and learning (cognitive, social, emotional, and physical);
teacher-child interaction;
family engagement; and
cultural competence for working with a diversity of children (including children with special needs and dual language learners) and families.
Grant funds provided under this Act shall supplement, and not supplant, other Federal, State, and local funds that are available for early childhood educator preparation and professional development.

A State that receives funds under this Act for a fiscal year shall maintain the fiscal effort provided by the State for the activities supported by the funds under this Act at a level equal to or greater than the level of such fiscal effort for the preceding fiscal year.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}fund.#text: such sums as may be necessary for fiscal years 2014 through 2019
